The prices for ships/fitts in eve are based upon conversions into PLEX. PLEX, or the Pilots Licence Extension, is an item you can buy and sell in EVE that you can use to resub your account. ( yes, you can pay for your sub with ingame currency ). Their value floats on the market, but they're about a billion isk right now. You can easily convert ship values into PLEX and thereby get the price of them in USD. This isn't based on hourly whatever.

I wouldn't be too hasty to label No Man's Sky an MMO. While it's true that all people playing the game will be sharing the same universe, that universe is mindbogglingly huge and the game will apparently lack the features that would enable multiplayer, such as the ability to quickly locate and meet up with other players to face off in PvP battles or experience co-operative play. The chance of randomly meeting another player are in the same ballpark odds as winning the lottery jackpot. Perhaps even worse. HelloGames designed the game this way intentionally, so as to make their universe feel "lonesome and enhance your sense of wonder." The idea is that while it's extremely unlikely to meet another player, the possibility remains and actually meeting someone will be something truly special, for the few lucky souls that end up experiencing it. Can a game really be called an MMO if most of it's players end up never meeting anyone?

It took time and effort and that whats made it feel special, and almost real, or at least worth the time, its also what made the people you meet for 20mins while you was trying to make it through a zone become real friends (or enemy's) for ever.I nether  made it above mid level in UO, EQ, SWG or PS, (my favourite 4 games ever) but never did that detract from the experience. As literally everyone else has said before, No Man's Sky isn't a MMO, but Star Citizen certainly is. It's highly cooperative with a player-driven economy, multi-crew ships (capital ships require hundreds of players to man) and massive guilds. It has procedurally generated planets as well, only a lot more in-depth than NMS, with a rich history and lore similar to WoW. Far more more to be mentioned in the 'future of gaming' part, if only because it was the largest crowdfunded project ever.

Ugh... So many misplaced drama llamas in the comments. Seriously, all the people nagging about runescape and everquest and the proper timeline and all those pet peeves, have you forgotten the meaning of the words crash course already?

A crash course is not to teach you the exact way something functions or the intricacies withing a function. It is to give you an easily digest-able bite-sized source of information, so that you can get the general idea and an easier entry into your own studies of the topic.
This is for example why the physics videos are only like ~10mins long and not 5 hours. Each.

And that's just the meaning of the words, there is also the fact that these videos are kept to a certain time restriction, which inherently means there will have to be things left out as a matter of fitting things together.

So please, stop bitching and realize that this particular part of the series was not aimed at you as a devoted MMO player, but to people who don't yet have a decent understanding of the topic.

Good crash course all around. I think it left a lot on the cutting room floor. For one, MMORPGS have a special kind of staying power compared to the young upstarts in casual gaming. WoW, EveOnline, Elder Scrolls and the rest are built around a community of a few hundred thousand and can sustain itself for years. Casual games like Farmville and Candy Crush need to constantly expand. Its why even though Farmville and its spinoffs had tens of millions of players at its height, they still burn out in a couple of years.

I think the community aspect could have used some more time too. Online communities became a thing because games were initially designed to be hard. In Vanilla Wow, the end levels were raids and raids took hours and NASA level of coordination. That difficulty and also the lack of in game tutorials to direct you on your own, created the communities that made WoW and gaming famous. WoW indirectly forced players who wanted to improve to meet other players, learn tricks and exploits. Along the way, you meet artists and musicians and stories spread. Again comparing it to casual games, the community there is big but shallow. There just isn't as much you can bond with on even the most difficult level of Candy Crush.

Some constructive criticism crashcourse. First of all, the first half of the video felt more like a glorified lead up to a discussion about Eve Online's economy system. Which is not only unrepresentative of MMORPG, but only tangentially related to the topic. Second, you failed to include a few big things about MMORPGs here's a short list of what you missed, just to name a few:

Runescape and its longevity
The golden age of Asian MMORPGs from Korea and Japan(where a lot of WOW's mechanics were dervied and first tried)
The closure of EA-Land and its last moments (and the simulation of an apocalypse)

This list is far from incomplete and I know you can't possibly talk about everything. But I do feel like using half of the video to talk about spotty MMORPG history and the other half on EVE's economy is not representative of a good history on MMORPG. The history of video games is important and I appreciate what your channel does about it. But I hope you'd actually deal with video game history with some journalistic intent instead of what kind of feels like an excuse for a topic to discuss.

Cheers, and more power to everyone who works there.

It wasn't mentioned, but EverQuest was the start of the modern MMORPG, Ultima Online came before it, but EverQuest was the first 3D MMORPG to take off (Meridian 59 came before it, but EQ popularized the genre).

Basically, WoW's developers loved EQ, but didn't want it to be so harsh, so they emulated it while making a lot of systems more accessible, as well as making it more quest (task) driven, which used the lore built and established by the Warcraft universe. Just... you know, if you wanted to know more about how the history of MMORPGs. :D

Final Fantasy XI came before WoW, and was also heavily influenced by EQ (the development team used to play EQ so much, they actually held meetings inside the game), and it was very successful, but shortly afterwards, WoW came out and became the phenomenon we all know about.
Woohoo, we're onto the MMORPG era.
